title: Handle more edge cases for an `ArgStr` prefix
body:
This filter can now catch all edge cases, instead of just UTF-8 prefixes. It uses a new function I added to os_str_bytes that can take advantage of some internal assumptions with minimal overhead.

I don't think the filter was being used for anything that would make the correctness matter, but it sets a good precedent. Plus, it removes the last use of `ArgStr::as_raw_bytes` outside of debugging code.

title: Remove the last unsafe block
body:
Closes #1594

This was relatively clean. All uses were compatible [except one](https://github.com/dylni/clap/commit/da0f50c676adf4730b8e09d58f3a158b26b3064b#diff-8c72fb1556bf0997bc60e808a97dd851L812). Another is now [improved to not truncate](https://github.com/dylni/clap/commit/da0f50c676adf4730b8e09d58f3a158b26b3064b#diff-8c72fb1556bf0997bc60e808a97dd851L1329). But, most changes only replace [`OsStr`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ffi/struct.OsStr.html) with `ArgStr` to avoid repeated conversions.

Notes:
- The MSRV for os\_str\_bytes is listed [here](https://github.com/dylni/os_str_bytes#rust-version-support). For common platforms, it's 1.32.0. Others didn't provide [OsStrExt](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/os/unix/ffi/trait.OsStrExt.html) or weren't supported by Rust until more recently.
- There's a minor difference in how lossy conversions are done. `OsStr` has its own implementation that was used previously and adds less [`REPLACEMENT_CHARACTER`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/char/constant.REPLACEMENT_CHARACTER.html)s. To give the same result now would require converting to `OsStr` before the lossy conversion, which would be slower.
- Should `osstringext.rs` be renamed to `argstr.rs`?

title: Allow rustc inline small functions across crates (-5.5 kB)
body:
<!--
If your PR closes some issues, please write `Closes #XXXX`
where `XXXX` is the number of the issue you want to fix.
Each issue goes on it's own line.
-->
As we all [know](https://stackoverflow.com/a/37639889), rustc cannot inline functions from extern crates unless they are either generic (subject to monomorphization) or explicitly marked as `#[inline]`. Or unless the programmer enabled LTO which is slooow.

This situation is sad because clap would actually benefit from inlining: a great deal of our API consists of very short functions.

Functions that ARE NOT marked as `#[inline]`:
* Generic functions; rustc can handle them on its own.
* Functions containing loops. It rarely makes much sense to inline them, but I may be wrong here.
* Functions containing more or less complex logic.

Everything else is inlined. `cargo bloat` shows the resulted binary has been shrunken a bit.

title: One less giant macro (-0.5 kB)

title: Add ArgPrecedenceOverSubcommand app setting
body:
`ArgPrecendenceOverSubcommand` is an app setting that changes if argument values should be greedily consumed instead of stopping when a subcommand is encountered. See #1721 for further explanation. See #1031 and [0c223f](https://github.com/clap-rs/clap/commit/0c223f54ed46da406bc8b43a5806e0b227863b31) for when the initial change was made.

There should probably be further community discussion on the correct default.

Signed-off-by: David McNeil <mcneil.david2@gmail.com>

title: Make debug output show names of args along with hashes
body:
<!--
If your PR closes some issues, please write `Closes #XXXX`
where `XXXX` is the number of the issue you want to fix.
Each issue goes on it's own line.
-->
Talk is cheap, so let me cut to the chase:

Before;
```
DEBUG:clap:ArgMatcher::inc_occurrence_of: arg=10706354686124900129
DEBUG:clap:ArgMatcher::inc_occurrence_of: first instance
DEBUG:clap:Parser::groups_for_arg: name=10706354686124900129
DEBUG:clap:Parser::parse_opt: More arg vals required...
DEBUG:clap:Parser:get_matches_with: After parse_long_arg Opt(10706354686124900129)
DEBUG:clap:Parser::get_matches_with: Begin parsing '"foo"' ([102, 111, 111])
DEBUG:clap:Parser::is_new_arg:"foo":Opt(10706354686124900129)
DEBUG:clap:Parser::is_new_arg: arg_allows_tac=false
DEBUG:clap:Parser::is_new_arg: probably value
DEBUG:clap:Parser::is_new_arg: starts_new_arg=false
DEBUG:clap:Parser::add_val_to_arg; arg=output, val="foo"
DEBUG:clap:Parser::add_val_to_arg; trailing_vals=false, DontDelimTrailingVals=false
DEBUG:clap:Parser::add_single_val_to_arg;
DEBUG:clap:Parser::add_single_val_to_arg: adding val..."foo"
DEBUG:clap:Parser::groups_for_arg: name=10706354686124900129
DEBUG:clap:ArgMatcher::needs_more_vals: o=output
```

After:
```
DEBUG:clap:ArgMatcher::inc_occurrence_of: arg="output" [hash: 10706354686124900129]
DEBUG:clap:ArgMatcher::inc_occurrence_of: first instance
DEBUG:clap:Parser::groups_for_arg: name="output" [hash: 10706354686124900129]
DEBUG:clap:Parser::parse_opt: More arg vals required...
DEBUG:clap:Parser:get_matches_with: After parse_long_arg Opt("output" [hash: 10706354686124900129])
DEBUG:clap:Parser::get_matches_with: Begin parsing '"foo"' ([102, 111, 111])
DEBUG:clap:Parser::is_new_arg:"foo":Opt("output" [hash: 10706354686124900129])
DEBUG:clap:Parser::is_new_arg: arg_allows_tac=false
DEBUG:clap:Parser::is_new_arg: probably value
DEBUG:clap:Parser::is_new_arg: starts_new_arg=false
DEBUG:clap:Parser::add_val_to_arg; arg=output, val="foo"
DEBUG:clap:Parser::add_val_to_arg; trailing_vals=false, DontDelimTrailingVals=false
DEBUG:clap:Parser::add_single_val_to_arg;
DEBUG:clap:Parser::add_single_val_to_arg: adding val..."foo"
DEBUG:clap:Parser::groups_for_arg: name="output" [hash: 10706354686124900129]
DEBUG:clap:ArgMatcher::needs_more_vals: o=output
```

This is enabled only in debug, release doesn't suffer from the additional `String` cost.

Closes #1803

title: Remove almost all #[doc(hidden)]
body:
<!--
If your PR closes some issues, please write `Closes #XXXX`
where `XXXX` is the number of the issue you want to fix.
Each issue goes on it's own line.
-->

The infestation has been contained, majority of the patients has been cured, and those who weren't fail into one of these groups:

* Hidden `AppSettings` variants that are not exposed to user but used by clap itself. I'd prefer extracting them into separate enum, but this is not priority right now.
* Macros. I guess this explains it. Maybe I'll see into converting them into functions, but it's not an immediate concern.
* Such methods as `App::_build` and friends. The basically exist because clap has no distinction between "builder" and "built app" at type system level. I'll be looking into it too.

title: debug_assertion validations
body:
Closes 5 issues. And provides the way we will be doing validations for programmer errors.

`debug_assertions` will be enabled when no optimizations exist. So, when people are using `clap` and use a test for it, this panicking happen. But if they build a release to distribute binary, this would not happen. In fact, the checks would not even occur making it more performant.

title: Update the documentation regarding which features are enabled by default
body:
Update the documentation regarding which features are enabled by default. I also made the formatting in `README.md` more consistent, and made the documentation in `src/lib.rs` match what is written in `README.md`.

Keeping these two files in sync appears to be error prone. I suggest using something like [Tagref](https://github.com/stepchowfun/tagref) to have these files point to each other so contributors are reminded to update both together. (This PR does not set that up, however.)

@CreepySkeleton @Dylan-DPC

Closes #1430

title: style: fix comma placement for valid values when using arg_enum
body:
When using `arg_enum`  and the user mistypes the parameter, the valid values are printed like this:

`valid values: A ,B ,C`

Note the position of the commas; this patch fixes their position to get placed right after the item:

`valid values: A, B, C`

title: Fix `-- subcommand` error
body:
https://github.com/clap-rs/clap/blob/b86bf25c189e0b57ebe7f21df9c772295ace08cb/src/parse/parser.rs#L468-L468
This line of comment says that only positional arguments follow `--`. So there is no legit args like `-- subcommand`. So we shouldn't emit subcommand mismatching error with `--`. Is that correct? I'm not pretty sure:-/
Closes #1722 
BTW, this commit fixes two typo.

title: Allow missing docs on arg_enum
body:
<!-- DO NOT DELETE THIS LINE! Internal hack, the shame is on you, bors! -->
<!--
If your PR closes some issues, please, put `Closes #XXXX`
lines to this comment (no quotes), where `XXXX` is the number
of the issue you want to fix. Each issue goes on it's own line.

YOUR COMMENT GOES BELOW
-->

I'm using `warn(missing_docs)` on my whole crate but I get warnings of `arg_enum` because it adds the function `variants()` which has no doc. This will fix the warning.

title: Allow replacing input on the fly
body:
<!-- DO NOT DELETE THIS LINE! Internal hack, the shame is on you, bors! -->
<!--
If your PR closes some issues, please, put `Closes #XXXX`
lines to this comment (no quotes), where `XXXX` is the number
of the issue you want to fix. Each issue goes on it's own line.

YOUR COMMENT GOES BELOW
-->
Closes #1603 

I tried several different ways of implementing the above requested feature but failed because they always ended up trying to manipulate the input which is a no-go because it was a plain `Iterator`. And then the #1693 was filed, and reading it made me think that maybe we should allow input to be changed. So, I extracted it out and made it do the replacing.

title: Added HelpRequired AppSetting
body:
Closes #1683 

There are likely some problems with my solution to this issue. I would be thankful for a review!

title: WIP: Extract subcommands into separate trait
body:
Not-yet-working-but-almost-there "multiple traits" approach. More or less done, what's left is to catch some bugs and adapt tests/examples.

For the record: it took so long because of RL stuff (who would have thought?) and because [there was a detailed description of the experience I've had here, but it was deleted because it contained a lot of profanity and emotional notes]. 

As the only person alive that understands how the derive works (if you won't blow your own horn, nobody will do it for you, yeah), I'd like to made a statement: we Do need the refactoring.
